channel.title: Swedish Pirate Party may get seat in EU Parliament
channel.description:
STOCKHOLM (Reuters) – Sweden's Pirate Party, which wants to reform copyright law, could ride a wave of discontent over tighter control of computer file-sharing all the way into the European Parliament in June. The jail sentences handed out last month to the four Swedish men behind The Pirate Bay, one of the world's biggest free file-sharing Web sites, have given a boost to the namesake party among young voters in Sweden, a recent opinion poll showed. "It is definitely something that has put the spotlight on our issues," Christian Engstrom, the party's top candidate for the European Parliament, told Reuters. "And it has demonstrated why it is so important, because the legal machine, if it's allowed to continue, is going to crush the Internet, starting with the Pirate Bay and then continuing on to other enterprises." A DN/Synovate poll ahead of the Europe-wide vote in June showed the party, which is not linked to the Web site though some of its views coincide with those voiced by the Pirate Bay defendants, winning 5.1 percent of the Swedish vote. That would be enough to secure the party, which wants to deregulate copyright, abolish the patent system and a decrease the level of surveillance of the Internet, a seat in the European parliament. The party was founded in 2006 and won only 0.6 percent of the vote in the Swedish general elections that year. The leader of the Pirate Party, Rick Falkvinge, believes that new Swedish laws, that for instance allow copyright holders to track down the IP-numbers of suspected file-sharers, are the main reason for the sudden popularity. "We're seeing a shockwave of new repressive legislation that is seriously jeopardizing the core of our civil liberties," he said. "People are starting to wake up to that fact." What will decide the outcome for the party is simply the question of whether its sympathizers will turn up to vote in the election that is usually plagued by low voter turn-out. Torbjorn Larsson, associate professor of political science at Stockholm University, said there was a risk some of the Pirate Party supporters won't show up. "Young people have a tendency not to vote. But if this issue stays on the agenda up to election day, it will make a big difference," he said.
sauce: http://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20090506/od_uk_nm/oukoe_uk_sweden_pirateparty;_ylt=AlMteOeqshlyCf8Ss.i5YhntiBIF Pretty sweet.. They've been gaining quite a bit of votes over the years.

Congratulation.

item.title: Swedish Pirate Party may get seat in EU Parliament
item.dc:creator: @dragonfire455 dragonfire455
item.description:
@dragonfire455 wrote:

[quote=“bowserjr2, post:8, topic:277792”][quote author=cooper link=topic=366709.msg2779868#msg2779868 date=1241751781]

At least they don’t want to watch everything everyone does just because the Recording companies make a war against their costumers and gives shitty products with few good alternatives.
[/quote]You do realize both “Vänsterpartiet” and “Miljöpartiet” are aganist IPRED and all that junk? Piratpartiet are trying to remove Patents which would result in chaos

Heard about Miljöpartiet was against it, but Piratpartiet is not going to or should get to much power thats right. Patents and Copyrights like they work today should be changed, but not removed, have you a source on your last statement about Piratpartiet?

Uriko’s post had the line near the middle.

That would be enough to secure the party, which wants to deregulate copyright, abolish the patent system and a decrease the level of surveillance of the Internet, a seat in the European parliament.

Thanks, but the patent system should be abolish and replaced by something much better.
Hopefully EU will to something good, instead of the stupid directives that removed rights of the people.[/quote]Explain your reasoning, people deserve to have protection on their created products.

Read full topic
